unnormalised: The fuel gauge in my trusty old Maruti 800 was perpetually hovering near the "E." It wasn't that I was perpetually broke (though there were times!), but more that I had developed a strange relationship with the petrol pump near my house in Andheri. It was almost a daily ritual, a quick top-up of ₹500 worth of petrol, just enough to get me through the day's commutes. I figured it was better than filling the whole tank; kept the car light, you see.
normalised: The fuel gauge in my trusty old Maruti eight hundred was perpetually hovering near the "E." It wasn't that I was perpetually broke (though there were times!), but more that I had developed a strange relationship with the petrol pump near my house in Andheri. It was almost a daily ritual, a quick top-up of rupee five hundred worth of petrol, just enough to get me through the day's commutes. I figured it was better than filling the whole tank; kept the car light, you see.

unnormalised: My brother, Arjun, a mechanical engineer from IIT Bombay, never quite understood my logic. “You’re wasting money, bhai!” he’d exclaim. “Buying petrol in small quantities is always more expensive per liter! And think about the extra trips to the petrol pump – that’s burning fuel too!" He’d go on and on, citing fuel efficiency figures in kmpl, comparing my fuel consumption to the average of cars in its class.
normalised: My brother, Arjun, a mechanical engineer from I-I-T Bombay, never quite understood my logic. “You’re wasting money, bhai!” he’d exclaim. “Buying petrol in small quantities is always more expensive per liter! And think about the extra trips to the petrol pump – that’s burning fuel too!" He’d go on and on, citing fuel efficiency figures in kilometer per liter, comparing my fuel consumption to the average of cars in its class.

unnormalised: One particularly hot day, the temp outside was hitting 38°C, I decided to drive down to Lonavala. Arjun, of course, took this as an opportunity to launch into another lecture. "Look, the tank holds 35 liters, right? Lonavala is about 83 km from Mumbai. At, say, 15 kmpl, you’ll need almost 6 liters one way. So, a full tank is a must!" He even offered to fill the tank for me as a “road safety measure”.
normalised: One particularly hot day, the temperature outside was hitting thirty eight degree celsius, I decided to drive down to Lonavala. Arjun, of course, took this as an opportunity to launch into another lecture. "Look, the tank holds thirty five liters, right? Lonavala is about eighty three kilometer from Mumbai. At, say, fifteen kilometer per liter, you’ll need almost six liters one way. So, a full tank is a must!" He even offered to fill the tank for me as a “road safety measure”.

unnormalised: I reluctantly agreed. The petrol pump attendant filled the tank, which cost a whopping ₹3500. It felt like a fortune! But as I drove, I couldn’t help but notice the car felt…different. Lighter, more responsive.
normalised: I reluctantly agreed. The petrol pump attendant filled the tank, which cost a whopping rupee three thousand five hundred. It felt like a fortune! But as I drove, I couldn’t help but notice the car felt…different. Lighter, more responsive.

unnormalised: The drive was smooth, the ghats were beautiful, and for the first time in ages, I wasn't constantly checking the fuel gauge. Reaching Lonavala, I’d used just under a quarter of the tank. Arjun, naturally, was waiting for my call. "So?" he asked, a smugness creeping into his voice.
normalised: The drive was smooth, the ghats were beautiful, and for the first time in ages, I wasn't constantly checking the fuel gauge. Reaching Lonavala, I’d used just under a quarter of the tank. Arjun, naturally, was waiting for my call. "So?" he asked, a smugness creeping into his voice.

unnormalised: "Okay, okay, you were right," I admitted. "The car felt better, and I didn’t have that constant anxiety about running out of fuel." I even dared to calculate the mileage using the full tank as the start point and estimated using a fuel app that Arjun recommended, and by the time I got back to Andheri, after another week of driving, it was about 16 kmpl, a whole kilometer more than what I expected.
normalised: "Okay, okay, you were right," I admitted. "The car felt better, and I didn’t have that constant anxiety about running out of fuel." I even dared to calculate the mileage using the full tank as the start point and estimated using a fuel app that Arjun recommended, and by the time I got back to Andheri, after another week of driving, it was about sixteen kilometer per liter, a whole kilometer more than what I expected.

unnormalised: I still make trips to the petrol pump. I will probably still fill ₹500 worth, sometimes. But now I know I’ve been a bit of a duffer, and I have a far better idea of how many kilometers my Maruti 800 can really do to the liter.
